description: From the Latin tribrachys, from the Ancient Greek τρῐ́βρᾰχῠς (tríbrakhus), from τρῐ- (tri-, “tri-”) +‎ βρᾰχῠ́ς (brakhús, “short”). Compare the French tribraque.

entries.meaning: (prosody) A metrical foot consisting of three short syllables.
examples: For your foote tribracchus of all three short, ye haue very few trissillables.

definitionGroups.group: A figure or object having three arms or branches.

examples: In a recent examination of the registers of the Ryde Philosophical Society, Mr. Martin has found, as I have been informed through Mr. Westropp’s kindness, the entry, that the flint tribrach was presented to the collection by the late Dr. Martin in 1853, with other objects from Ventnor, and as having been obtained on the shore at that place.

entries.meaning: (surveying) A circular platform on three legs, each having levelling screws, used to connect a theodolite to a tripod.
examples: An optical plummet, built into either the tribrach or alidade of total station instruments, permits accurate centering over a point.
